 You know, one of the things that really annoys me about the gay pride movement is that it oftens takes organizations or people, who are actually good and do good a lot of good things in society, and entirely judges and/or condemns them in whole based on their ONE view regarding homosexuality. It just looks hypocritical to me because gays want people to accept them and not judge them regardless of that one issue of homosexuality, but they want to condemn something like the Boy Scouts or Dobson in full, all over one issue. It's like condemning someone who spends his life doing humanitarian work just because he disagree with you on the death penalty or something.
 
 Given this thread I think it's important to say that the Boy Scouts are a good organization that does a lot of good things, and teach the kids involved in the organization to take care of people and be better citizens. Their views on homosexuality heve never even been much of an issue, until the gay pride movement went after them. Your movement's targeting of this organization has been a PR nightmare, and backfired because most people know that the Boy Scouts are a good, reputable organization, and most people DON'T judge them the way you do. Not to mention your court losses over it.
 
 Their purposes are (according to their FAQ)
 
 1. Character Development
 2. Spiritual Growth
 3. Good Citizenship
 4. Sportsmanship and Fitness
 5. Family Understanding
 6. Respectful Relationships
 7. Personal Achievement
 8. Friendly Service
 9. Fun and Adventure
 10. Preparation for Boy Scouts
 
 (Ooh, sounds downright demonic!! emoticon_rolleyes Those dastardly scouts.)
 
 They hold food collection services for the needy, they help keep parks clean, engage in environmental intiatives and cleanup projects, they work with habitat for Humanity, they work with the Red Cross, and do a lot of other good things too. 
 
 In Dec 2005, the Senate passed the Support Our Scouts act which encourages govt. support of the BSA, by a vote of 98 to 0! So apparently your gay-pride-friendly senators do not think there is enough of a problem with discrimination to withdraw support from the BSA, let alone oppose it. Not a single vote against them.
 
 So the question is, will you acknowledge these things, and that they are mostly a good organization? Or will you only focus entirely on your pet issue, and condemn them in entirety? I'll judge them on the whole picture, thank you, rather than by one single issue.

So while they still do good things, their image will be forever tainted by the fact that they discriminated against people just as Thomas Jefferson's image is somewhat tainted by the fact that he owned slaves (but I also believe TJ treated them well and paid them for their work, something most slave owners didn't do).

 
 Indeed they were better treated under Jefferson than a lot of slaves. Nevertheless, slaves they were. Here's a fascinating account by a former slave of Jefferson, from the 19th century. Sorry to be off-topic, but it's an interesting read.
